name: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition
description: Winner of more than 200 Game of the Year Awards, Skyrim Special Edition brings the epic fantasy to life in stunning detail. The Special Edition includes the critically acclaimed game and add-ons with all-new features like remastered art and effects, volumetric god rays, dynamic depth of field, screen-space reflections, and more.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7/8.1/10 (64-bit Version) Processor: Intel i5-750/AMD Phenom II X4-945 Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GTX 470 1GB /AMD HD 7870 2GB Storage: 12 GB available space
recommended_requirements: OS: Windows 7/8.1/10 (64-bit Version) Processor: Intel i5-2400/AMD FX-8320 Memory: 8 GB RAM Graphics: NVIDIA GTX 780 3GB /AMD R9 290 4GB Storage: 12 GB available space

reviews.review_text: Game was and still is so cool, but what's more remarkable to me is how easy is to look for/install/use the mods this time. I usually play the standard mode, sometimes due to my laziness, but this game has quite a few excellent mods, especially if you are looking for a nice immersion and realism, a couple of things that you couldn't find at the original skyrim. This mixed with the new graphics from the special edition makes it SO enjoyable, even when you role-play warming up for 5 minutes next to a fire pit. Mods i use: - Unofficial Skyrim Special Edition: this fixes most of the bugs of the game - Campfire: Lets you build a campfire and different sorts of tents - True Storms: Intensifies the original weather of Skyrim, making it look much tougher. (Thing i most appreciate of this mod is how you can listen the rain falling on the roof while you are inside a cabin. - Frostfall: Depending on how difficult you want it, you can even freeze to death and rain makes you be wet and get colder faster - Wet and Cold: Same thing but mostly for NPCs. Also includes some other features like blurry screen when you look up while it's rainning or snowing. - Point the way: Since i'm looking for some realism i avoid fast travelling, this is why i got this mod, which shows me the way to every city at every crossroad. - Lampposts of Skrim: Lamp posts on the main roads, but just what is necessary, not plenty of them. - Waves: Now beaches with waves :D - Better horses: Now horses go faster than you by foot, something that makes kind of sense. - Less agressive animals: Just makes less agressive small animals like rats or crabs. Was kind of ridiculous to see a crab trying to fight imperial soldiers. - Hunter's Reward - Better prices: Able to skin and sell pelts for a reasonable price in case you wanna play as a hunter. - iNeed: To eat, to drink and to Sleep is now necessary and rewardable. - Holidays: Skyrim has special days like our christmas and all that stuff - Expanded Carriage Service: Carriage service in places where you couldn't find them before, like Morthal or Dawnstar. - Rich merchants of Skyrim: Merchants have more money to buy, meaning that you don't need to walk around all skyrim to sell the stuff. (1000 septims was humiliating for a merchant TBH) - Run for your lives: When a dragon attacks people run off instead of trying to smack the dragon. - When vampires attack: Same with vampires - The Paarthurnax Dilemma: Lets you spare his life.  - Immersive patrols SE: Since there's a civil war going on, it's weird not to see any battle along the way until you join one of the sides of the war. With this mod you can find these fights while you walk around. Make other kind of patrols available, like the dawnguard. - Practice Dummies: You can use them to improve your skill till level 30 out of 100. That means that you don't need to deal with badass foes with the skill 'i barely know how to hold the sword'. - Mammoth Pelts: You can skin mammoths, something that i still don't get why it wasn't allowed in the original game. - Dog followers are Huskies: Makes it cooler and makes sense too since Skyrim is the north. - Whistle: Lets you whistle to the horse to make him come over, avoiding to search for the damn horse every time he flees from a battle. - NPC's Run and Walk at your pace: exactly what the mod says. - Animal poverty: Animals don't drop gold. Like they have a bank account or something... - MamTuskPowderGrind: You can grind mammoth tusk to make its powder, an ingredient that was so hard to find and wasn't allowed (don't know why) to make it out from the normal tusks. - Enhaced blood textures: MORE BLOOD! - Open cities Skyrim: No loading screen when you get into a city - Immersive Citizens: their behaviour and dialogues are more real. - RLO: Realistic Lights Overhaul. Also makes darkness darker, so no need to download 'darker nights' BTW, i got them in this order and all of them work properly
Now just need to wait for the Special Edition modding to get going.
Hey it was free im not complaining.

I've played this game throughout multiple times, I never modded it as I prefer games to run Vanilla. Meaning for all those hours I dealt with Vanilla Skyrim graphics and I can confirm that there is a HUGE difference. As soon as I started in the wooden carriage with the prisoners/Ulfric, I turned to the left and couldn't stop looking at the wooden carriage. I instantly messaged my friends telling them to look around as soon as they start, and they responded exactly the same. 'It's beautiful.'  Also people are saying that their is no difference between Original Skyrim & Skyrim Special Edition. I have around 200+ hours on Skyrim on Steam and around 1000+ hours on PS3 Skyrim. Old Skyrim feeled so bland, dark colours. Don't get me wrong, Skyrim is and will be one of the best games to be made, ever. However Original Skyrim felt so bland, there were parts of the game that felt colourful, such as spells or Whiterun. However this edition feels like it has the colours of a TellTale game. It has a more cartoon feel to the colours. It sounds negative however once you see this on your own screen you'll know exactly what I mean. It's basically Original Skyrim, with beautiful colours and everything feels more smooth.  It feels like a totally new game, I've played hundreds of games for thousands of hours, and not one has ever felt as good as this, I only have a couple hours on this game as I write this review, however throughout time I'll end up with thousands of hours on this game.  I would have been happy to pay for this game however Bethesda was generous enough to give us owners of the Original Skyrim including all DLC the whole Special Edition for free. Which comes with all the DLC. Which is honestly amazing, Bethesda could have made hundreds of thousands of dollars by making us pay for it. They made an extremely generous move on their end and for that I respect Bethesda alot more.  I'd recommend this game for anyone looking to have a whole new experience with the gaming genre. Some games are for certain groups of people who like different games, however Skyrim, I'd recommend for anyone and everyone. Get this if your PC is decent enough to run it which you can find out on the Store page by looking at the recommend specifications.  - TJ

It seems like this game was really about remastering the game for consoles where mods are not accessible. For console gamers, this really would be a dramatic improvement.   But for my fellow gamers of the PC variety, you can get a nicer looking Skyrim that runs with twice the FPS by adding a few simple graphics mods to the original. I got it for free, so I hate to complain, but if you are looking to buy it again for a percieved graphical improvement, I'd recommend against it and just mod the original.

I don't do reviews often but I feel the need here after getting to, yet another infuriating bug.   I'm giving this a negative review because they didn't fix any quest bugs. Every bug that bothered me in the initial release is still present. You would think that was the first place you would look at to release an enhanced edition. The fact that little things like the gildergreen not disappearing when the new, smaller tree is planted is not fixed is simply inexcusable. Those are things people fix with common console commands. You cannot convince me that that wasn't an easy fix for your programmers. It just seems like a lazy development project given to the visual effects team to keep them busy and sharp while being able to charge $60 for a 5 year old game that you made no real improvements in GAMEPLAY to. It's the Michael Bay of videogame development. I probably wouldn't have played the game if not given for free after paying nearly $100 to buy the original game and expansions. Thanks, I genuinely mean that. I also have to knock you on taking form over function. I'd have preferred you give me a patch to fix all the crappy bugs over a visual overhaul. This seriously makes me not as interested in buying future Bethesda games. I don't want to wade through bug after bug to get to a rich storyline. I've played since morrowind. I like the story and the basic engine. I am too disrupted by bugs though to enjoy it. I honestly cannot believe that those weren't the first fixes. It makes me think less of you as a developer.

People that write a negative review tend to only mention the things that did not get fixed or the thigns that did not improve. So as a nice change of pase I'll be providing you a list of the things that Bethesda ACTUALLY changed/improved:  1. Further draw distances 2. Better atmosphere 3. An amazing reduction in texture pop-in (Like trees, plants etc) 4. No more mountain flickering  5. Lipsync fix (at least for me, can't speak for the rest of the community) 6. Smoother graphics transitions 7. Directx11 and 64Bit (Duh)  A lot of mods won't be needed anymore thanks to this special edition  Is it worth it when you haven't recieved it for free? Hell no, wait for a sale.  *This review will be updated the more I get into the game*

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is considered by most to be one of the best games of all time, so it is no surprise that Bethesda would decide to re-release it with an updated engine. However, many people are having difficulty recommending the game, hence the 'Mixed' reviews. Whether or not I recommend you buy Skyrim depends on who you are.  If you already own Skyrim and all its DLC then you will receive this for free, obviously Bethesda realised that it was preposterous to expect people who already owned the 'Legendary' edition of the game, to re-purchase the 'slightly more Legendary' edition. So if you are able to receive this game for free then there is honestly no reason not to delve back into this amazing word.  You will not immediately be able to tell the difference between this version and the original (especially if you installed a ton of mods), but persevere and you will see that there are differences. Sharper colours, god rays and improved lighting effects are a welcome improvement over the dull greyness in the original. Water looks and flows more realistically and the foliage is more dense. People have claimed that no bugs have been fixed, which is true to some extent. However, some graphical glitches that I found very irritating in the original have been fixed, plus an annoying sound bug that would cause voices to stutter and skip is gone.  Obviously none of this is anything mods cannot do, and this is why many do not recommend this game. I must confess I'm no expert in modding, but many mods will need updating to work with this re-release. This means that currently mods are not a numerous as the original Skyrim.  If for what ever reason you are not eligible to receive this game for free, do not buy it. If it ever goes on sale in the future then it may be worth paying for and hopefully by that point many mods will have been released for this version of the game. But at this point it is not worth buying for £29.99 even if you have never played Skyrim before. The only people I can see paying full price to play this are people who are buying Skyrim of the first time on the PS4/Xbox one.  Also people have reported crashes, I personally have had a very stable experience on my GTX 970, but it is important to consider that the last patch introduced crashes on some machines. I believe they are working on another patch to fix the crashing.  I'm not sure If I recommend this or not, I received it for free which means I'm massively biased. If you received it for free like me you obviously have nothing to lose, but if you have to spend £29.99 I would avoid doing so until either it goes on sale or the modding community take advantage of this games huge potential for mods. As usual this is a case when the modding community will eventually make this worth buying.  *EDIT*  After playing this version of Skyrim for over 80 hours I have encountered tons of graphical glitches that were not present for me in the Legendary Edition, so whereas before I was in two minds about whether or not I recommend this or not, now I absolutley do NOT recommend you spend money on this.

You can now loot the Torturers Hood in the tutorial. 10/10  In all honesty, I've been looking forward to this. Not only is it now 64bit for added stability, but I think the mods created or expanded upon will be even greater than before.  In regards to the 'enhanced visuals' in this version, they are there. It's not something fantastic like a solid ENB or overly noticeable, but there are small added features that seem to just make it look much better. In comparision to Vanilla Skyrim, it blows it out of the water; even if you don't think so at first. I was someone who spent hours playing the game, but also spent countless, frustrating hours trying to always make my game look perfect. While I was able to get my original Skyrim modded to look amazing, I always felt the need for more.  There has been so much I couldn't do in the game that I wanted to because I focused so much on making the game look perfect. However, I feel that this enhanced version not only makes it look more attractive in subtle ways, I feel that I will finally be excited to get into this game again and spend a far more amount of time playing than worrying about visuals.

This is 'STILL' a great game, sure it's an expensive remake of an older game (if you don't already own Legendary Edition), but the performance gains are well worth it in my opinion, plus this will reinvigorate the community to put out new mods that weren't already out there. the one thing I'm bothered by in these other reviews is everyone is saying that 'Alt-Tab is working now', I have never had an issue with Alt-Tab with Legendary Edition, but I do have issues with it on Special Edition.  so here are my pros and cons:  Pros:  1) Far better performance than the old versions. My load times are down significantly, I used to have to wait 5-10 minutes sometimes with heavy modding, now even with Realistic Lighting Overhaul and a few other graphic mods I get a standard 40-60FPS (*see pro 2) on ultra and load times at most 15 seconds.  2) More stable FPS. As stated in Pro 1, I now have a good 40-60FPS when I'm in an area that I'm at 60FPS in, I stay at 60FPS, if I should enter an area where it drops to around 40FPS I get from 40-45FPS on average. there have been the occasional drops to 20fps, but that was while testing a mod I was working on.  Cons:  1) Other people claim their Alt-Tab is working well, so this may not be an issue for you, but when I Alt-Tab, I get a black screen followed by the game image coming back on, but it clearly has a different window open, just not visible, and when I Alt-Tab again, it allows me to switch to a different window properly. This would be ok for me, if it weren't for the fact that occasionally it will not go back to the game and it doesn't crash but makes it to where I have to force quit the game, losing any progress I have made.  2) This is a minor con, but a con nonetheless, it's still the same old game we have played for hundreds to thousands of hours, not even much of a visible graphic difference to me (Though I did use enb and texture mods on the original). there are no new quest lines that I have noticed, I would hope, but doubt it will happen, that they release at least a couple small free, or really cheap, dlc for it to add new NPCs, companions, and quests.  This is my honest assessment of Skyrim Special Edition. I'm glad I got it for free though, as I probably wouldn't have payed $40 for it, but if you don't already have it, then you probably haven't played it, so I suppose the value is all relative to the purchaser.

Eventhough the original Skyrim has more modding capabilities at the moment due to SKSE, Skyrim Special Edition runs much more smoothly FPS wise in most areas where the original Skyrim had major issues.  You also can mod Skyrim SE without SKSE and with the 64 bit engine there's no Z-fighting and no crashes. It's so good I recommend getting the Skyrim Legendary Edition so you can get the Special Edition for free, that way you have both and you can chose yourself which one you want to play.  Imo SE is better than the original. It runs better and it's much more beautiful even without modding. If you get the mod 'Alternate start' via the Nexus you have lots of replayability:  10/10 Would replay again.

Edit: It seems that many mods have been ported over, and many skse-dependant mods have now been abandoned and new inferior skse-free versions that work on all platforms are being developed. This turned out worse than I thought, it actually set back the modding community quite a bit.  Even if SKSE for special edition is ever completed, there will have been no more development on SKSE-based mods in that time.  Old Review:The special edition of Skyrim is pointless currently. It looks marginally better than an unmodded original skyrim, but that's about it. The main issue is that it breaks literally every mod, and the script extender will have to be rebuilt for it (and that will take a lot of work). Ironically this remaster does the opposite of bringing the game into this generation because SKSE and tools like FNIS are necessary for all the mods that 'modernize' skyrim. The entire point of the special edition seems to be trying to console-ify skyrim modding. And because consoles can't get a script extender, Bethesda doesn't care about breaking it on PC (afaik).  Also, they didn't even integrate the bugfixes from the unofficial patch into the special edition, they actually broke the unofficial patch. So this version of the game will be incredibly buggy compared to the original skyrim with the USKP.

For the price and amount of changes and comparing it with other games released in this year I have to say no. I got my copy for free (I own every DLC for original) and every Skyrim owner should get this copy for free even after this day they buy all DLCs.   It has enhanced visuals, better lighting and most important it is 64bit thus effectivley lifting the limit for amount of mods that can handle.   Textures are a bit better but I have seen textures from mods for regular Skyrim that are way better than these.   Faces and hair are almost identical to the original and that is why Bethesda didn't want early receivers of the game to show game's intro (only when player exit from on-rails intro part they could stream or upload). In this intro part, the very first thing that player see are the bad faces, bad hair and low polygon count is more than obvious. With this, Bethesda obviously sends message that they don't care to properly finish their games. From a company with such resources I expected much more.  This would be amazing if original game was like this, but it is really something unfinished. If Bethesda is small company then yes, but Bethesda is giant now and this is not the proper way to treat their fans. So I have to look for mods to enhance this because I can't stand those blocky faces, hair, bad textures and so on.  The only real advantages this version of Skyrim are: no mods limit, better loading times and shadow. Everything else, mods did way better with original version.

This'll change as soon as they fix the FPS-based physics bug (anything higher than 60fps causes a lot of hiccups) that SOMEHOW made it through the engine change that SHOULD HAVE removed it. It is unbearable to cause ALL items in the room to go ABSOLUTELY BUCKNUTS when you open a DOOR. If you are near a body of water, you will hear a lot of the sound of you getting in and out of water, in addition to sometimes swimming ON LAND. I killed the Captain in the intro sequence by looking up, causing the cart to smack right into her face, and couldn't continue past the first guy on the chopping block. He never got his head cut off because she wasn't there to push him down. This needs to get fixed, and if the issue is like how Skyrim 2011 was, it's hard-coded into the game engine, so ONLY the devs can fix it, no mods will ever be able to touch it.   It just boggles my mind how they ported Skyrim into the Fallout 4 engine, Fallout 4 being a game that CAN run above 60fps no problem, and yet THAT bug, the ONLY game-breaking bug that mods didn't and couldn't fix, made it through!

TLDR: You may certainly give it a try, only a little bit later.    64bit support; no SKSE yet though (10/30/2016)   It certainly looks way better than vanilla skyrim (but not on the level of modded-skyrim better, not even close)   Native borderless window support (however it constantly breaks into 'not responding' state on every loading screen, as if something locks the render; oh well, nothing serious, I guess)   No SkyUI support for now (and vanilla UI just sucks chicken ♥♥♥)    You  still  need to download mods to fix bugs  (nice remaster guys, no really, it's great)   You need to have 'bethesda account' in order to download mods (and any official mod now will disable achievements, which is totally understandable; however using native cheats via console doesn't disable achievements... like why?)   You can  not  create 'bethesda account' from the game itself, which is very nice (well, we have borderless window support now, haven't we?)   Still no FOV slider (luckily we still can use console to solve this)   And finally, now you can crash to desktop without any mod (hurray!)

I have to say, I am truly dissapointed. After putting over 500 Hours into Skyrim (on console too), I am VERY dissapointed in Bethesda. A few things: If you have any mods it won't let you get acheivments, which doesn't make sense because you can simply go into the command console and turn god mode on. Even if they are mods which change the colour of moths, it disables acheivments. Also, sprint is now not a hold and sprint, it is a toggle. I know it is a small thing but you can really notice it in combat or going places.  Also Bethesda have made absolutley 0 effort to optimise the menu. I understand the menu has been 'made' for consoles, but they could have at least done SOMETHING.  This is literally no different than the original Skyrim, except from an ENB (Where bethesda have pretty much just added God rays and lowered the brightness).  I did get this for free as I do own Skyrim and all of the DLC, however I am really let down by Bethesda.  If you are contemplating buying this, I would save your money.  Buy the original and get an ENB, it will save you a fortune,

This isn't a review of the game, just the remaster. Some people are having bugs and crashes with the game. I have not had any so far, so if you are thinking of buying this, you could risk it, but maybe wait until they have been ironed out. The graphics dont look much better than the original, sure it has better lighting and water quality, but the textures still look the same. I run the game in High Quality, 1080p, and it just looks like a slight graphical enhancement. I played on Ultra, and then after writing the review saw a sevre drop in frames. I have a AMD 6300K, GTX 960 2GB and 8GB RAM. Not a high end system but the game set me to play at Ultra by default. Having mods on this version of Skyrim disables the achievements, even if it is just a graphics mod or a survival mod. Because of this I have not looked into the mods but I am told that there is mods avalible, even one to re-enable mods. Bethesda please fix this, although theres a fix it's a ♥♥♥♥ idea, and there really is not need for a fix.  All that being said Skyrim is a great game and I have had hundreds of hours of fun with it, both on console and PC. This is the same experience but with prettier lighting.

Just fantastic. For me, compared to the older skyrim, I have no lag, no crashes, its just so smooth compared to before. I used to have a lot of lags when in combat, when hitting npc's and such, nothing of that anymore. I can only look forward to the mods comming over too. The 64 bit engine is a huge step forward. I really don't get people who got the game for free, and still can complain about it. You literally have no reason to complain, you haven't given anything at all for this game. If they atleast charged you, complain freely, but getting it free, and complaining, just come on., there is litterally no downsides of this, you get an upgraded engine for free, even if the new graphics isnt ''wow'' you got the mods for that, with more capabilities than ever before.

I absolute love The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim And when i saw that Bethesda was releasing a Special edition i was really hyped And also when i read that everyone who have The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Legendary Edition whould get this for free, i didn't know where to put myself. And now that the game is finally here i have to admit, it wasn't like i hoped it would be.  But Don't get me wrong! The remaster looks absolutely amazing then the original. I find the other reviews for this game to be thoughts that aren't truly their own. So, please, stop that argument because it's false. Secondly, to each their own opinion. I say that meaning...your own opinion, that you came up with. Not someone else.  Now...on to the review for this game. I had owned Skyrim for PS3 way back in 2011. I played it for probably 20-30 hours and somehow during the transition from my military deployment location on back to the states, I lost my save. I was upset and refused to play it anymore. I then bought the 'ultimate' edition here on Steam back during a summer sale and still, didn't really play it.   Now...the special edition is out. Yes, mods are not fully available as they were before on Nexus mods, but they will be back. The Skyrim modding community is one of the best out there and we all know they will deliver. If you want all the mods and glory of the original, stick with that, this game installs separately. It doesn't overwrite your past saves (although most old saves won't work). In this case, buy it. Vanilla this is better than vanilla original. You may still want to install USSEP from  nexusmods.com  to fix all the little bugs.  2. You want to see what modding is like, and this looks like a good game to start out on. In this case, give it a few months. Like I said above, this version hasn't caught up yet, and needs to be tinkered with for a while to match the original in this regard. Once the mods are caught up, the original game will be obsolete, and THEN you should buy this.  Now, about the actual game:  Skyrim is a masterfully-designed, open-world rpg that everyone should at least try out. You'd be doing yourself a disservice if you didn't. It's brimming with interesting content and things to do, though admittedly it's rough around the edges when it comes to character progression and bugs. That's what the massive modding community is for, and Bethesda has gone out of their way to make modding easy, and even fun. You'll enjoy the game even without mods, and when you inevitably find small problems with it, you'll be able to find a mod for just about anything. I've played my fair share of Skyrim, on both console and PC, and while I acknowledge that the special edition was geared largely towards bringing the game to new platforms that is no excuse for the game running as well as a crippled monkey with polio. I'm running it with an Nvidia 980 and 32 gb of RAM and experiencing insane frame drops and these weird gray splotches on npcs and trees. I've tried it on every setting from low to ultra and while dropping it to low, which I shouldn't have to do, helps a little with the frames nothing I do gets rid of the splotches. In addition, the start up time is awful. It sits at a black screen and only after the music has been playing for a few seconds does the Bethesda logo pop up and then it finally gets to the main menu. Sometimes it doesn't even do that and just crashes. I've tried it with no mods and with the unofficial patch, but nothing seems to fix these problems. As of right now, the original skyrim with some graphical mods is a far better game than this 'special edition.' If it gets patched or otherwise optimized I will change my review, because at its core Skyrim is a fantastic game. This attempt at a remaster is a very poor representation of that.  UPDATE: The game for whatever reason by default selected my integrated graphics card rather than my nvidia card. After fixing that and fiddling with a few settings, I managed to crank the settings to ultra and eliminate both the splotches and most of the frame issues. The only issue now is the fact that the game looks near identical to the original.

The audio is more compressed and sounds slightly worse on headphones, and the textures were upscaled for some reason even though they look exactly the same.
